name: Personal Development
description: Ready to engage in personal development that grows your skills as a leader? Whether your goals are to advance to another position or to lead from where you are, this pathway will take you on a journey to improve your ability to lead from where you are and to reach your potential in the future.
objective: Engage in personal development activities that grow your skills as a leader.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.description: Recognize your own health and wellbeing as an imperative, not just a “nice to have.” Wellness is required of leaders.

activities.name: Creating Health Habits - L@WW Video, What does health and well being mean to me?
activities.description: Hear from PSA DM Okenge Yuma Morisho, House of Indigenous Learning Lead T'oila McIntyre and panelists who will share experience creating healthy habits.

This online video library, available through our health care provider, includes a wide variety of topics within health and wellbeing in the workplace. Accessible on @Work. A single topic consists of half a dozen videos, all under ten minutes each.
To access the LifeSpeak Library videos, click "group," type "lifespeak" for the password, and you're in. :)

From a blog "about the world of leadership, learning, development, coaching, and life at work." podcast episode: "Wellbeing, leadership and authenticity."
Quote: "… in a leadership role is in some way, you’re expected to be well. Just naturally. You should be a shining example of being well in an organization. And the simple fact is: you’re not always going to be in that place. You’re only human.”

activity_type.name: Listen
activity_type.description: There are so many things to listen to from podcasts and audio books to radio shows and even music to help achieve your goals.

activities.name: The Science of Well Being Course
activities.description: The Science of Well Being is a course from Yale available free from Coursera. Participants will engage in a series of challenges designed to increase their own happiness and build more productive habits. As preparation for these tasks, Professor Laurie Santos reveals misconceptions about happiness, annoying features of the mind that lead us to think the way we do, and the research that can help us change. Participants will ultimately be prepared to successfully incorporate a specific wellness activity into their life.

steps.name: Step 2
steps.description: Analyze your strengths and supports. In this step, you'll identify the strengths and supports that promote your resiliency and ability to navigate challenge and adversity, and identify and articulate the supports you still need to be fully resilient.

activity_type.name: Read

activities.name: Building Resilience
activities.description: Have trouble getting by when the going gets tough? Everyone wants to perform well when the pressure's on, but a lot of us withdraw in times of stress or adversity. If you can build your resilience, you'll have an easier time facing new challenges and earn a valuable skill to offer employers.Five training techniques to prepare for difficult situations, and five strategies for reflecting on them afterward. Find out where you are on the resilience scale, identify where you want to be, and learn strategies to close the gap.

activity_type.name: Watch
activity_type.description: Only the best of video content from YouTube, Vimeo, and any other source that helps the learning goal.

activities.name: Emotional Agility by S. David
activities.description: Emotional agility is a four-step approach that allows us to navigate life's twists and turns with self-acceptance, clear-sightedness, and an open mind. In her more than twenty years of research, Susan David has found that no matter how intelligent, resilient, or creative people are, when they ignore how situations or interactions make them feel, they miss opportunities to gain insight, getting hooked by thoughts, emotions, and habits that prevent them from reaching their full potential. Emotionally agile people experience the same stresses and setbacks as anyone else, but they know how to adapt, aligning their actions with their values and making small changes that lead to a life of growth.

activity_type.name: Read
activity_type.description: From real paper books to study abstracts and blog posts; the classic written word enhancing your learning in many ways.

activities.name: EdX Course: Becoming a Successful Leader
activities.description:
In this course, you will learn what successful 21st-century leaders look like and how you can adopt their inclusive leadership style. Using research and best practices, as well as stories from great leaders and everyday people, you will practice empowerment, accountability, courage, and humility—key leadership skills linked to inclusive, successful teams.

This online course seems appropriate for new/aspiring leaders that are looking to develop inclusive leadership skills. Also relevant for Step 8 (mentorship), Step 9 (presence), and Step 10 (personal philsophy).

NOTE: You can access the course resources and discussions via the "audit" option. For full participation with graded assignments, there is a fee for the "verified track" option.

Self-discovery and awareness means understanding one's thoughts, feelings, values and background and how they impact the success of the interaction and relationship, or how they may influence one's work.

Review and reflect on how you demonstrate or don't demonstrate this competency. Consider some of the behaviours listed in this resource and assess your own competency. Consider developing a plan to enhance your own self-discovery and self awareness.

activities.name: Harvard Implicit Assumptions Test
activities.description: Here is a tool that allows each of us to discover hidden cognitive biases. Most people are aware of their own overt biases, but it is very difficult for us to become aware of our covert biases. This is a test that can be taken by each individual for their own benefit.Please note by completing the assessment you are consenting to your personal information being stored in the US. (User test results are anonymized and added to data sets to contribute to on-going research.)

activities.name: Thanks for the Feedback: The Science and Art of Receiving Feedback Well
activities.description: The authors of the classic bestseller Difficult Conversations return with Thanks for the Feedback, the first book to assert that receiving feedback well is a skill that can be taught and refined. With humour and clarity, Thanks for the Feedback takes an honest look at why feedback can feel so hard to hear, and gives readers the framework and tools needed to metabolize challenging information and use it to fuel real change.

activities.name: Sustained Learning and Development (Indigenous Relations Behavioural Competency)
activities.description:
Sustained Learning and Development means continually increasing your ability to build and maintain respectful and effective relationships with Aboriginal people. Review and reflect on how you demonstrate or don't demonstrate this competency. Consider some of the actions, such as:

Go to Aboriginal communities and organizations to learn about their culture and business as part of learning and development plan.Seek and utilize informal learning situations responsibly. Examine your own performance and seek feedback internally and externally to improve performance.Integrate feedback into development plans and activities. After reflection, develop a plan as to how you can enhance your competence in this area.

activities.name: Circle of Courage as a Framework for Leadership
activities.description: The Circle of Courage model of development was first described by by Larry Brendtro, Martin Brokenleg, and Steve Van Bockern in their book Reclaiming Youth at Risk. The model is grounded in Indigenous philosophies of child rearing and contemporary resilience research, and describes how to create an environment in which we can grow and flourish. While the model began with youth, it’s a powerful framework to support how we think about developing ourselves and others as leaders.This activity asks you to read about the framework and consider how four specific aspects can serve your growth as a leader.
activities.moderator_notes: Needs to have the one-pager linked. Look in Teams - General>Files >one-pager folder. Thanks!

activities.name: Evaluate Your Leadership Presence
activities.description:
Look for opportunities when you have a chance to practice your leadership presence, and have time to reflect after. When you are ready to do so, make contact with someone who will be part of the event (say, a presentation to an executive group, or facilitating a community of practice event). Tell them that you'd like them to act as a friendly observer of your presence, and that you'd like their feedback after the event. 

After, have a conversation with your friendly observer. What did they notice? Are your efforts succeeding? What do you want to change? What aspect of your presence do you need to focus on next? Make note, and track your progress in whatever way makes sense to you. Some people might record their reflections on video or voice, some might keep a notebook--do what works for you, but be sure to come back to your reflections to plan for your next opportunity to practice.

activities.name: The future of leadership in the public sector: what's wanting to emerge
activities.description: Written for Apolitical, this article is written by Abe Greenspoon, Organisational Health Lead at Statistics Canada and Jennifer MacLeod, Owner and Executive Coach at Jennifer MacLeod Consulting.Are old values holding you back? This article considers what's needed to shift away from a mindset to control situations and others to one that incorporates human values of empowerment, cooperation, collaboration and trust. This is a helpful read for while you're sorting out your own philosophy of leadership.

category.name: Leadership
category.description: Building your leadership skills is something you can do in whatever role you're in now, as well as something you may look towards for future roles. As BC Public Service leaders, we aim to develop our core leadership competencies, as well as role-specific ones that apply to certain positions. Wherever you are today, you'll find useful learning here for developing your leadership skills.
